name: Vilazodone
summary: Vilazodone is an antidepressant used for the treatment of major depressive disorder (MDD) in adults.
description: Vilazodone, marketed under the brand name Viibryd, is an oral antidepressant that combines selective serotonin reuptake inhibition (SSRI) with partial agonist activity at the 5-HT1A receptor. This dual mechanism is thought to increase serotonergic activity in the brain and improve mood regulation. It is indicated for the treatment of major depressive disorder in adults and is generally taken once daily with food to improve absorption.

contraindications: Use with monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) or within 14 days of stopping an MAOI
Hypersensitivity to vilazodone or formulation components
monitoring_required: Mood and suicidal ideation, especially at initiation or dose changes

items: Treatment of major depressive disorder in adults

sections.text: Combines selective serotonin reuptake inhibition with partial agonist activity at the 5-HT1A receptor, enhancing serotonergic neurotransmission.

adult.oral: Start at 10 mg once daily with food for 7 days, then increase to 20 mg once daily. May increase to a maximum of 40 mg once daily after a minimum of 7 days at 20 mg, based on response and tolerability.

sections.text: Initial antidepressant effects may be observed within 1–2 weeks, with full effect typically requiring 4–6 weeks.

other: May increase risk of suicidal thoughts and behaviors, especially in young adults
Risk of serotonin syndrome when combined with other serotonergic agents
May cause hyponatremia, particularly in older adults or those on diuretics

items: Signs and symptoms of serotonin syndrome

sections.pregnancy: Limited human data; use only if potential benefit justifies risk
sections.lactation: Unknown excretion in human milk; caution advised
sections.geriatrics: Increased risk of hyponatremia; monitor electrolytes if symptomatic

sections.text: Gradually reduce dose over at least 1–2 weeks to reduce withdrawal symptoms.

items: Taking with food significantly increases absorption and reduces GI side effects
Dual mechanism may benefit certain patients who have partial SSRI response
GI upset is most common early in treatment and often improves over time
